source_textbook: Creating Educational MicroSims with Generative AI

questions.question: What is this course about?
questions.answer: This 14-week undergraduate course teaches you how to use generative AI to create educational interactive web-based simulations called MicroSims. You'll learn to leverage AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude to generate, refine, and debug simulation code while applying pedagogical principles to ensure your simulations are educationally effective, accessible, and engaging.

questions.question: Who is this course designed for?
questions.answer: This course is designed for teachers, educators, and instructional designers who want to create interactive learning experiences. You don't need to be a professional programmer—basic familiarity with programming concepts like variables, loops, and functions is helpful.

questions.question: What is a MicroSim?
questions.answer: A MicroSim (Micro Simulation) is a small, focused, interactive web-based simulation designed to help learners understand a specific concept. Unlike comprehensive simulation software, MicroSims embrace purposeful simplicity, targeting one learning objective at a time with clarity and precision.

questions.question: What makes MicroSims different from other educational software?
questions.answer: MicroSims are unique because they combine five key characteristics: (1) Small and focused—each addresses a single concept, (2) Interactive—users manipulate parameters and see immediate results, (3) Web-based—runs in any browser without installation, (4) Embeddable—easily placed in textbooks and course materials, and (5) AI-friendly—structured for rapid generation by generative AI tools.

questions.question: What tools and materials do I need for this course?
questions.answer: You need: (1) Access to a generative AI tool like ChatGPT or Claude, (2) A modern web browser with developer tools, (3) A text editor or IDE (VS Code recommended), and (4) A GitHub account for version control and deployment. All required software is free.

questions.question: How long does it take to create a MicroSim?
questions.answer: With AI assistance, basic MicroSims can be created in minutes to hours rather than weeks or months. The AI generates initial code from your description, and you iterate through 2-4 refinement cycles to polish the result.

questions.question: What JavaScript library do MicroSims use?
questions.answer: Most MicroSims in this course use p5.js, a JavaScript library designed to make creative coding accessible to beginners. p5.js provides simple functions for drawing shapes, handling animations, and creating interactive controls.

questions.question: What is p5.js and why do we use it?
questions.answer: p5.js is a JavaScript library that makes creative coding accessible with simple functions for drawing, animation, and interaction. We use it because it has a gentle learning curve, works in all browsers, has excellent documentation, and integrates well with AI code generation.

questions.question: What are the main parts of a p5.js sketch?
questions.answer: Every p5.js sketch has three main parts: (1) Global variables declared at the top to store canvas dimensions, simulation parameters, and UI references, (2) The setup() function that runs once to initialize the canvas and controls, and (3) The draw() function that runs continuously (~60 times per second) to update and render the simulation.

questions.question: What is Bloom's Taxonomy and why does it matter for MicroSims?
questions.answer: Bloom's Taxonomy is a hierarchical framework classifying educational learning objectives into six cognitive levels: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and Create. It matters for MicroSims because different cognitive levels require different types of simulations.

questions.question: What are the six levels of Bloom's Taxonomy?
questions.answer: The six levels from lowest to highest are: (1) Remember—recall facts and basic concepts, (2) Understand—explain ideas and interpret meaning, (3) Apply—use knowledge to solve problems, (4) Analyze—examine relationships and compare components, (5) Evaluate—make judgments based on criteria, and (6) Create—produce original work.

questions.question: How do I match a MicroSim type to a learning objective?
questions.answer: First, identify the action verb in your learning objective. Match the verb to a Bloom's level using standard verb lists. Then select MicroSim types proven effective for that level. For example, 'Calculate velocity' (Apply level) suggests a simulator or calculator MicroSim.

questions.question: What is a Learning Graph?
questions.answer: A Learning Graph is a directed graph representing concepts and their prerequisite relationships within a knowledge domain. It shows which concepts must be understood before learning new ones. Learning graphs guide the sequence of instruction and help AI systems recommend personalized learning paths.

questions.question: What is Cognitive Load Theory?
questions.answer: Cognitive Load Theory describes how mental processing capacity limits affect learning. It distinguishes three types of load: intrinsic load (inherent complexity), extraneous load (burden from poor design), and germane load (effort building understanding). Good MicroSims minimize extraneous load.

questions.question: What is the PRIMM methodology?
questions.answer: PRIMM stands for Predict-Run-Investigate-Modify-Make, a pedagogical framework for teaching programming. Students first predict what code will do, then run it to check, investigate the structure, modify it to observe changes, and finally make their own version.

questions.question: What is responsive design in MicroSims?
questions.answer: Responsive design ensures MicroSims adapt to different container sizes and screen widths. Instead of fixed pixel positions, responsive MicroSims use relative calculations like canvasWidth/2 for centering. The windowResized() function detects size changes and adjusts the layout accordingly.

questions.question: How do I embed a MicroSim in a web page?
questions.answer: Use an HTML iframe element: <iframe src="path/to/main.html" width="100%" height="450" style="border: none;"></iframe>. The border: none style removes the default iframe border for seamless integration.

questions.question: What files make up a complete MicroSim package?
questions.answer: A complete MicroSim directory contains: index.md (documentation with metadata), main.html (HTML wrapper), style.css (styles for embedding), script.js (p5.js sketch code), data.json (configurable data, optional), and metadata.json (Dublin Core metadata).

questions.question: How do I make a MicroSim responsive to width changes?
questions.answer: Implement the windowResized() function to detect size changes, then call resizeCanvas(newWidth, canvasHeight). Create an updateCanvasSize() function that reads the container width with document.querySelector('main').offsetWidth. Recalculate all position-dependent elements when the canvas resizes.

questions.question: What is the difference between setup() and draw()?
questions.answer: setup() runs exactly once when your sketch starts—use it to create the canvas, initialize variables, and set up controls. draw() runs continuously (about 60 times per second)—use it to update positions, apply physics, check conditions, and render graphics. Never create sliders or buttons in draw().

questions.question: How do I add a Start/Pause button?
questions.answer: Create a button with createButton('Pause') in setup(), position it, and add a click handler. Use an isRunning boolean variable. In the click handler, toggle isRunning and update the button text. In draw(), wrap your update code in if (isRunning) { ... } to respect the state.

questions.question: How do I debug a MicroSim that isn't working?
questions.answer: Open browser developer tools (F12), check the Console tab for error messages. Use console.log() to print variable values during execution. Temporarily add visual markers to verify positions. For AI-assisted debugging, copy the exact error message and relevant code, then describe expected vs. actual behavior.

questions.question: Why does my MicroSim show a blank canvas?
questions.answer: Common causes: (1) Missing or incorrect createCanvas() call in setup(), (2) Error in code preventing execution—check browser console, (3) Canvas created but nothing drawn in draw(), (4) Background color matching shape color, or (5) Shapes drawn outside visible canvas area.

questions.question: Why don't my sliders affect the simulation?
questions.answer: Make sure you're reading the slider value in draw() with slider.value(), not just once in setup(). The value must be read each frame to respond to changes. Also verify the variable storing the value is actually used in your calculations—check for typos in variable names.

questions.question: Why is my animation too fast or too slow?
questions.answer: Animation speed depends on how much you change position each frame. Multiply your velocity by a small factor (0.1-0.5) to slow down, or increase values to speed up. You can also use frameRate(30) to reduce frame rate, but slider-controlled speed is more flexible.

questions.question: How do I handle AI hallucinations in code?
questions.answer: AI may invent non-existent functions or use incorrect syntax. Always test generated code immediately. Verify unfamiliar function calls against p5.js documentation. Be skeptical of 'convenient' features you haven't seen before. Cross-reference with working examples from this course.

questions.question: How should I structure my p5.js code?
questions.answer: Follow this order: (1) Global variables at top, (2) setup() function for initialization, (3) draw() function for rendering, (4) Helper functions for specific tasks, (5) Event handlers (mousePressed, keyPressed, etc.). Use descriptive function names and add comments explaining complex logic.

questions.question: How do I write effective AI prompts for MicroSims?
questions.answer: Include: (1) Purpose—what concept this teaches, (2) Canvas layout with specific dimensions and colors, (3) Visual elements—list every shape and label, (4) Interactive controls with ranges and defaults, (5) Behavior—what happens when controls change, and (6) Code standards to follow.

questions.question: How do I design accessible MicroSims?
questions.answer: Include describe() for screen readers, ensure sufficient color contrast (WCAG 2.1 AA), support keyboard navigation where possible, use minimum 16px text size for readability on smart boards, and provide visual feedback for all interactions.

questions.question: How do I use Claude Code for MicroSim development?
questions.answer: Claude Code is a CLI tool that integrates Claude directly into your development workflow. Instead of copying code back and forth, Claude Code can read and write files directly. Say 'Read sketch.js and add a reset button' and it will understand your existing code and make integrated changes.

questions.question: What are rules files and how do I create them?
questions.answer: Rules files provide consistent context to AI about your project's standards. Create a markdown file with sections for canvas standards, variable naming, code structure, control placement, and required elements. Reference this file at the start of AI conversations or include it in your project.

questions.question: How do I implement the push/translate/pop pattern for grouped elements?
questions.answer: Wrap related drawing commands between push() and pop(). After push(), use translate(x, y) to set the group's origin. Draw elements relative to (0,0). The pop() restores the original coordinate system. This lets you move entire groups by changing just the translate values.
